skill.name: managing-git
skill.description: Manages Git workflows including branching, commits, and pull requests. Use when working with Git, creating commits, opening PRs, managing branches, resolving conflicts, or when asked about version control best practices.

security_audit.summary: This skill is pure Markdown documentation with no executable code. Contains only Git workflow guidance, checklists, and command examples for user reference. No scripts, network calls, filesystem access, environment variable reading, or code execution capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: Developers often struggle with inconsistent Git practices leading to merge conflicts and confusing commit histories. This skill provides clear guidelines for branching strategies, commit conventions, and pull request workflows to maintain clean and collaborative repositories.
actual_capabilities: Provides GitHub Flow and Git Flow branching strategy diagrams and guidance
Defines Conventional Commits format with type definitions and examples
Offers branch naming conventions with ticket-based patterns
Includes pull request checklists and size guidelines
Shares common Git commands for daily workflows and mistake fixes
Lists commit validation criteria before pushing
limitations: Does not execute Git commands directly on user repositories
Does not integrate with CI/CD systems or Git hosting APIs
Does not resolve merge conflicts automatically
Does not enforce commit policies through hooks or server-side rules

Users can now sign in with their Google accounts.

best_practices: Make atomic commits with one logical change per commit to simplify reviews and rollbacks
Use descriptive commit messages that explain the 'why' behind changes, not just the 'what'
Rebase on latest main before creating PRs to keep history linear and reduce merge conflicts
anti_patterns: Avoid WIP commits like 'fix stuff' or 'updates' that lack context and purpose
Do not commit directly to main branch; always use feature branches with PR review
Avoid large PRs over 500 lines that overwhelm reviewers; split into smaller pieces

faq.question: What Git hosting platforms are supported?
faq.answer: This skill works with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and any Git-based repository. Commands and workflows are platform-agnostic.

faq.question: What are the size limits for pull requests?
faq.answer: Under 50 lines is XS (quick review), 50-200 is S (standard), 200-500 is M (thorough), and 500+ should be split when possible.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with Git hosting APIs?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and templates only. It does not execute API calls or integrate directly with GitHub, GitLab, or other platforms.

faq.question: Is my repository data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only documentation and templates. It does not read, write, or modify any repository files or Git data.

faq.question: Why are my commits showing merge conflicts?
faq.answer: Conflicts occur when multiple branches modify the same lines. Rebase your branch on latest main before creating PRs and stage changes interactively with git add -p.

faq.question: How does this compare to Git auto-merge tools?
faq.answer: This skill teaches Git concepts and best practices rather than automating merges. It helps users understand when to use rebase, cherry-pick, or merge strategies.
